item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[grid cols_nr="2"] [cell size="4" class="block-light content-bigger"]

About us

As a digital agency, our job is to take your ideas and make them greater. To create digital platforms and solutions that are greater than anything youâve ever used. To make easy ideas easier. [arrow] [/cell] [cell size="8"] [bar title="Graphic Design" progress="63%" markers="on"] [bar title="Wordpress" progress="87%" markers="on"] [bar title="Responsive Design" progress="75%" markers="on"] [bar title="Support" progress="100%" markers="on"] [/cell] [/grid] [grid cols_nr="4"] [cell size="4"Â class="block-dark content-bigger"]

What we do

We conceive, design and produce digital content and integrated experiences for web, mobile and the physical world. [arrow] [/cell] [cell size="3"]

Digital Story

  • Brand Insights
  • Consumer behaviors
  • Digital trends
  • Concept development
  • Content strategy
[/cell] [cell size="2" class="no-padding-lr"]

Motion design

  • Design-driven motion
  • 2D/3D Animation
  • Narrative storytelling
  • Programmatic animation
  • Information architecture
[/cell] [cell size="3"]

Brand

  • Brand identity
  • Art direction
  • Visual language
  • Brand voice
  • Photo direction
[/cell] [/grid] [grid cols_nr="2"] [cell size="4" class="block-light content-bigger"]

Meet the team

We are a team of creative professionals working together, with you, to turn your ideas into an adventure. We start by figuring out the best way to bring your ideas to life in the most creative, logical way possible. Daniel is our project manager, and a whizz in progressive enhancement. Consider Fuse as your next partner for digital production development. [/team-member] [team-member name="Eric Hussmann" image="http://pixelgrade.com/demos/fuse/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/member4.jpg" title="Founder / Partner" social_twitter="#" social_facebook="#" class="image-right border-bottom"] Iâm the founder/ partner, and a whizz in progressive and enhancement or responsive web. [/team-member] [team-member name="Mike Galloway" image="http://pixelgrade.com/demos/fuse/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/member5.jpg" title="Lead Designer" social_twitter="#" social_facebook="#" Â class="border-bottom"] Iâm the front end developer, and a whizz in progressive and enhancement or responsive web. [/team-member] [team-member name="Ramone Fuss" image="http://pixelgrade.com/demos/fuse/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/member6.jpg" title="Junior Developer" social_twitter="#" social_facebook="#" social_linkedin="#" social_pinterest="#" Â class="border-bottom"] Consider Ramone as your next partner for digital production and mobile app development. [/team-member] [/cell] [/grid] [grid cols_nr="3"] [cell size="4" class="block-color content-bigger"]

Our office

Connect with us. Let's make something great together. [arrow] [/cell] [cell size="4" class="block-dark no-padding"] [/cell] [cell size="4" class="block-dark no-padding"] [/cell] [/grid]

We help companies define and design for their clients successful digital experiences thanks to our theme design approach.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start blogging!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To delete a comment, just log in and view the post's comments. There you will have the option to edit or delete them.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Reminder: Design is still about words (gallery)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Some designers might think Iâm referencing the Call to Action, and thatâs true, but thatâs the low-hanging fruit. This goes much deeper. They say âa picture is worth a thousand words,â a quote attributed to the New York Journal-American editor, Arthur Brisbane. This could be true somewhat, however, it all depends upon the person you ask. A photograph can go a long way in terms of conveying emotion, building a brand image and creating individuality and personality to a design. Then why useÂ words in designÂ still? [quote author="Justin Jackson" link="http://justinjackson.ca/words.html"] At its heart, web design should be about words. Words don't come after the design is done. Words are the beginning, the core, the focus. [/quote] Thereâs some interesting science behind this questÂ Â ion of what jumps out. When you apply this science to your work, it can boost the results and satisfaction your designs deliver. [gallery link="file" ids="634,632,631"]

item.title: Design Quote
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This quote says a lot about the job of being a designer, about being asked to bring something new and meaningful to the world.
We are not complaining or anything though :)

item.content:encoded:
Some designers might think Iâm referencing the Call to Action, and thatâs true, but thatâs the low-hanging fruit. This goes much deeper.
Thereâs some interesting science behind this question of what jumps out. When you apply this science to your work, it can boost the results and satisfaction your designs deliver.

item.title: Design: Seeing Without Thinking
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Visual perception and pattern detection for designers.Â What your audience immediately sees without conciously thinking much about it and how to design for it. This is a very visual theme, merging pictures and text seamlessly, featuring a grid based, patchwork portfolio section and page that tempts your visitors.Â This goes much deeper in thinking.

What jumps out?

Some designers might think Iâm referencing the Call to Action, and thatâs true, but thatâs the low-hanging fruit. This goes much deeper. Thereâs some interesting science behind this question of what jumps out. When you apply this science to your work, it can boost the results and satisfaction your designs deliver. This is a phenomenon that occurs in the brainâs low-level visual system. Simply, preattentive Processing describes a limited set of visual cues the brain can rapidly process, what jumps out in your audienceâs mind.

Color and info layering

In our scenario, we are mapping census data to show how similar geographic areas compare to each other in terms of population, income, race, or education level. [caption id="attachment_601" align="alignnone" width="767"] Three maps with standard color palettes[/caption] Of course, the most inspired ideas come from the magical space in time between falling asleep and sleeping (if only I could remember them!). The idea should be strong enough to push you to action.

Give the Idea an Inspiration Shower

The seed needs to be soaked in an inspiration shower (patent pending). I hunt the interwebs for cool UI patterns and archive them in a massive PhotoShop file. For example, when working on YouTube TV I grabbed hundreds of examples of future UI from futurists like Jayse Hansen and Neil Huxley.
Designing and developing anything of consequence is incredibly challenging.
Sketching for me is the result of landing on a solution in my mind. I dont sketch to solve the problem, I sketch to describe the solution I see in my mind. I donât stop sketching until I transfer the whole system from my mind to paper. I have to understand the big picture of the product first and how every piece fits together. I tend to sketch out little UI patterns like how I would handle large numbers, dates and long titles, trying to solve potential UI issues before I get working on mocks.

Ship and Evaluate

Shipping is the ultimate test of your designs success. Successful design is design that converts. There are only three metrics that truly matter:
  1. How many users?
  2. How much time do they spend on site?
  3. How much revenue do you generate?
Data doesn't lie. What you build and ship either increases these conversion metrics or decreases them.

I agree with supporting type designers. I wish more of them let me serve their fish in my restaurant. This is changing for the better though.

Great articleâitâs been wonderful to see the evolution of rich web typography in the past few years, and I feel that given the accessibility and volume of information on the web, typography will become even more important to pixelpushers.

item.title: Web Design Is All About Typography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
95% of the information on the web is written language. It is only logical to say that a web designer should get good training in the main discipline of shaping written information, in other words: Typography.
Typography has one plain duty before it and that is to convey information in writing. No argument or consideration can absolve typography from this duty. A printed work which cannot be read becomes a product without purpose.
Information design is not about the use of good typefaces, it is about the use of good typography. Which is a huge difference. Anyone can use typefaces, some can choose good typefaces, but only few master typography.

Where to start

  • Web Typography
  • Five simple steps to better typography
  • A List Apart
  Credits:Â http://ia.net/blog/the-web-is-all-about-typography-period/
